text.front:
Ruti Bardenstein* and Mira Ariel
From location to conjunction, disjunction,
partition, exemplification and association:
Hebrew bein constructions
https://doi.org/10.1515/ling-2022-0115
Received July 22, 2022; accepted July 23, 2023; published online April 22, 2024
Abstract: Analyzing the diachrony of Hebrew bein, originally a spatial preposition
'within/among', this article traces several grammaticization clines associated with bein's
gradual evolution into a rich variety of functions within various constructions. While its
early function is purely locative, bein later participates in an array of constructions and
sub-constructions, where its syntactic status, its semantic meanings and functions, as
well as its discourse role, have shifted considerably. Bein may thus be part of a
conjunctive or a disjunctive construction, but it may also be part of an 'in any case'
adverbial, and later an 'anyway' discourse marker. It conveys different locative con-
struals ('within', 'among' and 'between'), but also various abstract symmetric relations,
such as 'difference', 'dispute' and 'separation'. Some bein constructions partition a set,
focusing on a subset of it, while in other cases bein serves as an 'all-purpose' preposition.
Nevertheless, our goal is to show how each grammatical, semantic and discoursal phase
is well motivated, given the previous phase. Based on written historical corpora, from
Biblical to contemporary Hebrew, we provide a step-by-step diachronic development
from earlier to later bein functions.
Keywords: conjunctions; constructions; disjunctions; grammaticization

1 Introduction
The topic of this article is the evolution of Hebrew bein 'inside, in the middle of, among,
between' (Ben Jehuda 1908-1959; Brown et al. 1907; Even Shoshan 1982) into a sur-
prisingly rich variety of meanings and functions it contributes to, among them: loca-
tion, conjunction, disjunction, partition, exemplification and association. The Biblical
(1a) shows an early function of bein, as a spatial preposition meaning 'among', but bein

All the developments exemplified above originate from the complex [bein X u-vein Y]
'between X and between Y' construction. A separate, additional path of metaphorical
extensions of the simple locative construction [bein NPs] 'among NPs' rendered this
bein a set partitioner (akin to partitive some), as well as an 'all-purpose' associative
preposition (standing for 'by', 'for' etc.) (see Section 4).
These semantic and syntactic changes, which turned a spatial preposition into a
partitive or a general associative preposition on the one hand, and to forming part of
a conjunction, a (limited) disjunction, a conjunction again, an 'any circumstance'
adverbial and finally an 'anyway' discourse marker on the other hand, are puzzling.
We trace here the small linguistic steps that must have gradually led to these rather
radical changes: We show that they were functionally motivated, and occurred
within specific Goldbergian constructions (Bybee 2003; Himmelmann 2004; Traugott
2008). We focus on the innovative bein constructions for each period we discuss
below but note that practically all older functions persist in later periods as well
(Hopper 1991), though at different frequencies.
Briefly, the initial function (1a) is typical of prepositional phrases, where a
figure ('it') is located in relation to some ground ('the living creatures'). It presents
the ground (the locating entity) as a formless, unstructured plurality (or collective)
of landmarks, and no definite space is delineated for the figure's location within
the ground (Talmy 1972). Disjunctions (1c), however, involve an alternativity
relation, typically between specifically two options (Ariel and Mauri 2019). We
therefore need to explain the shift into two distinct profiled alternatives in (1c).
Indeed, with the evolution of the complex prepositional correlative construction
(1b) the complement of bein profiles the relevant ground as two individuated
landmarks.
We will argue that once these landmarks are (i) extended to nonlocative entities,
(ii) are contextually construed as alternatives to each other and (iii) occur within an
irrealis context, a (limited) disjunctive reading is made available, free-alternative (or
"free-choice") (see Example (4) below). A syntactic detachment of the free-alternative
construction then gives rise to an adverbial indifference-disjunctive bein construction
(4c)-(4d). Finally, should the explicit alternatives be deictic markers used merely as
general placeholders for indefinite reference (Cf. English this and that), rather than as
pointers to specific entities (ko and kax both meaning 'this way, thus'), the two alter-
natives ('this way or this way', similar to 'one way or another') are interpreted as a
higher-level-category 'or' construction (Ariel and Mauri 2018). In such cases, a single,

abstract category is constructed ad hocly, and serves as the speaker-intended message.
In this collocative variant, the literal 'thus or thus' or 'one way or another' point to a
single abstract 'any case'.
We note that with the initiation of the Mishnaic correlative adverbial use (1c), the
construction was mobilized for argumentative strengthening of the main assertion it
modifies. This discourse function will be inherited by all of its descendants, as pre-
dicted by Bardenstein's (2021) Persistence Principle. Bardenstein's principle predicts
the retention of discourse functions associated with specific forms, rather than of
meanings per se. The claim is that it is the initial inference-based (argumentative)
motivation for change that persists (and can ultimately lead to a shifted meaning as
well). Since not all the diachronic changes undergone by bein involved argumenta-
tive strengthening, not all later functions manifest it. Specifically, the independent
diachronic path from locative to subset and a general associator are not accompa-
nied by argumentative strengthening.
The following sections tell the diachronic story of bein 'within, between', fleshing
out the details behind its evolution. We analyze the uses of bein in Biblical Hebrew
(Section 2), in Mishnaic Hebrew (Section 3), in Diaspora Hebrew (Section 4), in
Revival Hebrew (Section 5) and Contemporary Hebrew (Section 6). 3 Section 7 sum-
marizes the grammaticization phases involved.
2 Biblical Hebrew: from locative preposition to
conjunctive construction
We extracted all 249 bein 'within, between' tokens from the Hebrew Bible, written
between 1000 B.C. and early A.D. times. Biblical bein occurs in two syntactic
frames. As part of a simple PP, bein modifies a single NP and often means 'within'
(Section 2.1). As part of a complex conjunctive PP correlative, its complement is a
conjunction of two NPs, and its meaning is 'between' (Section 2.2). Whereas the
simple construction is predominantly a locative, the complex construction mostly
profiles a symmetric relation between two reference points. 4 The simple con-
struction will give rise to innovative uses in Diaspora Hebrew. The complex

3 Readers should be aware, however, that the written sources we rely on, Biblical Hebrew, Mishnaic
Hebrew, Diaspora Hebrew, Revival Hebrew and Contemporary Hebrew do not represent a contin-
uous history of natural transmission.
4 A relation between X and Y is symmetric if X bears the same conceptual relation to Y as Y to X.

already in Mishnaic Hebrew.
2.1 A simple prepositional phrase
The simplest syntactic structure found for Biblical bein is where the preposition takes
a single NP, as in (1a) above. We found 95 such tokens, the morphological and
syntactic/semantic breakdown of which is shown in Table 1.
The most basic meaning of bein 'within/among/between' shows it as a modifier of
a complement NP which is either collective or mass (e.g., srefa 'burnt.stuff') (4) 5 or,
more commonly, plural (54) NPs. Both types of NPs mostly stand for a non-
individuated ground (58, 61 %). Bearing in mind that bein 'within/among (an undif-
ferentiated ground)' will evolve into 'between (two identifiable landmarks)', it's
interesting to examine the frequency of cases where the ground happens to involve
specifically two reference points (we estimate at least 41, 43.2 %). First, some of the
plural NPs (e.g., anašim 'people' -see (3) below) denote two entities in the specific
context (at least 6, quite possibly many more). More importantly, many of the
complement NPs are morphologically dual (37), most of which (35) indeed refer to
two entities. Most of these are body parts that often come naturally in pairs (e.g.,
'feet', 'eyes'). These cases are crucial because the original 'within/among' bein mod-
ifies a continuous, homogenous ground. But once the ground happens to consist of
two individuated, noncontiguous, well-defined landmarks, there is no longer a single
undifferentiated region for the figure to be located in. This is when bein is used as
'between', rather than as among. The landmarks are construed as distinct from each
other, as is the space between them -the space between the eyes/feet is distinct from

Table 1 shows that the most frequent function of the simple PPs is as locative adverbs
(69, 72.6 %). But once it is the space between the two landmarks that is profiled by the
bein NP complement, this physical space can receive an extended metaphorical
interpretation (Brown et al. 1907). First, a single collocation (bein ha-ʕarbaim 'twi-
light') accounts for 11/12 time adverbials. These are metaphorically derived from the
locative adverbial (physical space > time interval). 6 Thus, locative and time adver-
bials together account for as much as 84.2 % of the simple bein PPs.
Next, the (implicit) physical space connecting the two landmarks can be further
metaphorically extended. It can be construed as an abstract, rather than a physical
link (or relation) connecting the two entities, which are no longer physical locations.
Note that just like the space between two landmarks establishes a symmetric relation
between them, so is the abstract link asserted here reciprocal. At first, this relation
needs to be explicitly specified. In the following copular complement case in Example
(3), the specified relation is one of 'dispute' (the same is true for the 1 VP complement).
(3)

The next phase already leaves the abstract relation implicit. It is contextually
inferred from the nature of the verb. An examination of the 9 verbal argument cases
reveals that all the verbs depict an act that executes a separation, typically dis-
tinguishing between two human entities, based on some abstract criterion (who is
'just' and who is 'unjust' in a dispute between them in Example (4)).

All in all, the syntactically simple bein (NP) structure mostly presents an undiffer-
entiated and non-prominent ground, which can only indicate a vague location (or
time) for the figure within the ground. The figure and the ground are not physically
distinguished at this stage. At the same time, a significant minority of the plural/dual
NPs refer specifically to two individuated, relatively more prominent landmarks. In
these cases, the ground region no longer subsumes the landmarks. It is limited to the
continuous space delineated between the landmarks. This is how we get an inferred
interpretation of bein, originally 'within/among (an undifferentiated ground)', as
'between (two specific landmarks)'. 7 Finally, a minority of copular, verbal and VP
complements (12 tokens, 12.6 %) no longer introduce locative landmarks, but rather,
entities standing in opposition to one another (typically human).
Biblical Hebrew naturally reflects different diachronic stages. Section 2.1 iden-
tified two general trends. First, a potential rise in the prominence of the relevant
discourse entities, from a non-prominent undifferentiated plurality landmark (e.g.,
'living creatures' in (1a)), through individuated (inanimate) landmarks (e.g., 'your
eyes' in (2) to humans standing in some opposition to each other) ('the two of us' in
(4)). Second, a metaphorical extension of the space between the landmarks has been
mobilized to express a symmetric interpersonal relation between the prominent
entities (e.g., 'dispute' in (3)). As we see below, this minority discourse profile, where
two prominent entities are involved in some symmetric relation becomes more
dominant in the complex bein PP constructions discussed in Section 2.2 and consti-
tutes a crucial step towards specifically a disjunctive relation (extremely prevalent in
Mishnaic Hebrew -Section 3).
2.2 Complex conjunctive PP correlative
Complex PP constructions are the more frequent structures for Biblical bein (154/249,
61.8 %). In these constructions the initial preposition bein 'between' takes conjoined
NPs, the second of which is often prefaced by a duplicate of bein, which is non-
referential, and is a dummy form (122, 79.2 %). See Example (5). 8

7 See Todaka (1996) for this and other differences between the complements of English between and
among (pertaining to identifiability, separation and competition).
8 Note that reduplicate (and rarely triple) bein tokens were counted as single occurrences.

We propose that this complex construction, which conjoins two individual reference
points, contributes crucial steps towards the evolution of the later (restricted) disjunctive
function in Mishnaic Hebrew. First, the minority trends observed above for the simple
PP construction, namely, the prominence of the entities involved and the abstract
symmetric relation between them are quite evident for this construction. Second, a new
relevant factor shows up, the irrealis context (see Mauri [2008] for the crucial role of
irrealis in evolving disjunctive constructions). Third, the symmetric relation between the
profiled entities is associated with some opposition between them, which facilitates their
construal as alternatives to each other. This is accompanied by an implicit need to decide
or choose between the two alternatives. Finally, as we see below (Section 2.2.3), three
examples show an interpretation that lies between conjunction and disjunction, quite
like free-alternative ("free-choice") or disjunctions (Ariel and Mauri 2018).
2.2.1 Motivating the correlative bein construction
The correlative construction in Example (5), literally 'among/within X and among/
within Y' seems to be rare typologically. We should therefore motivate its syntactic
evolution, as well as the semantic shift from 'within, among (undifferentiated) Xs'
(with 'between two Xs' as an occasional contextual inference) to an explicitly
encoded 'between X and Y'. Now, the initial bein token contributes the spatial
meaning in the complex construction. The conjunction (here u-) conjoins the two NPs
comprising the relevant landmark reference points. It is the second, duplicate bein
that is not transparently compositional, and in need of an explanation. Why did
speakers evolve this construction, and why with reduplication? Specifically, why not

directly evolve the more compact conjunction [bein (X ve-Y)] '[between (X and Y)]',
which is frequent in Modern Hebrew? 9
The key motivation behind the evolved complex construction, we propose, is
that it is conducive to the function sought by speakers. Specifically, the innovative
syntactic structure iconically reflects a symmetric relation between separate entities.
To get a feel for the motivation behind this innovative "redundant" conjunctive
construction consider the current English conjunctive examples in (7):
(7) a. The yearlings have great long bare spots in their sides and in their rumps.
(LSAC) 10
b. Reagan and Bush and Clinton all pointed to the growth in employment,
which happened in the eighties and in the early nineties.
(LSAC)
Presumably, the speakers in (7) could have avoided the "superfluous" repetitions,
opting for the shorter and more compact conjunctions in (8):
(8) a. ∼The yearlings have great long bare spots in their sides and rumps. 11
b. ∼Reagan and Bush and Clinton all pointed to the growth in employment,
which happened in the eighties and early nineties.
Note, however, that sides and rumps, and the eighties and early nineties may very well
be interpreted as referring to grounds denoting single space and time continuities
(respectively). Avoiding this reading is the motivation behind the longer variants in (7).
The ground is then construed as consisting of two separate reference points. As a
result, we are more likely to envision the yearlings as having spots on the sides, which
are separate from the spots on the rumps (in (8a)). Similarly, the employment growth
(in (8b)) is construed as comprising two separate intervals of growth, one pointed to by
the Republican presidents in the 80s and one pointed to by the Democratic president in
the early nineties. The repeated and here supports a distributive versus a collective
reading. We note that Chatzikyriakidis and Giorgos 2015 analyze Greek reduplicate
conjunctive correlatives (ke… ke…lit. 'and… and…', 'both…') as specialized for a
distributive, rather than a collective reading. The Hebrew bein correlative is partly
similar to this construction, although it's not quite distributive.
We propose that the reduplicate form (for and and for bein) creates a separation
between the conjoined elements (an iconic motivation). Consider (1b) again in
Example (9) below.

9 According to the Hebrew Academy of Language (10 July 2012), the compact structure is a much later
development, most likely from the Diaspora. The few Mishnaic cases are assumed to be copying
errors.
10 LSAC is the Longman Corpus of Spoken American English.
11 ∼ indicates an unattested example.

Recall that bein's original meaning is 'within, among', which introduces a continuous
region as its complement. If so, [bein (bet el ve-ha-ʕai)] could be interpreted as 'within
a single region covering both places'. But this is precisely what the speakers using
the complex PP construction wished to avoid. Their intended referent is the space
between these two places, such that the latter are taken as two separate reference
points, together delineating that space.
Now, when the reduplicated form is 'and' this separation forces a distributive
reading (as in Greek and English). When the relevant form is the locative preposition
bein, as in Hebrew, all we get is a blocking of a single, continuous region. In this way,
the Hebrew construction maintains the independence of each of the landmarks, but
in this case, it gave way to a 'between (individuated reference points)' interpretation,
later entrenched as part of the [bein (X u-vein Y)] construction. This continues the
trend of including prominent landmarks and/or reference points already noted
for the simple PP construction in Section 2.1. But in the complex construction, all
the relevant entities are prominent (as compared with about a third in the simple
construction). This is crucial for the evolution of the complex locative construction
into a disjunctive construction (see Section 2.2.3).
2.2.2 The functions of Biblical complex bein 'between' constructions
As mentioned above, [bein X u-vein Y] constitutes the great majority of the complex
bein PP constructions. The remaining 32 cases (20.8 %) omit the conjunction u, and
replace bein with a different preposition, le 'to', resulting in a different structure,
where bein governs a PP, rather than a conjunction (see Example 10).

( pp X le-Y)]
[ pp between ( pp X to-Y)]
This is a more compact syntactic structure. Note that the syntactic symmetry be-
tween the landmarks is lost, but the distinctness of X and Y is maintained because
bein takes two complements ('X to Y' is also not merged into a singular referent).

development in that (i) the relation between the reference points need not be
explicitly mentioned -it is implied by the verb meaning (e.g., 'judge'), and (ii) a
substantial minority involves the more compact 'between X to Y' construction
(41.5 %). All in all, more than two-thirds of the complex constructions are associated
with some abstract, nonspatial symmetric relation between prominent referents, as
opposed to 12.6 % of the simple constructions.
In addition, a majority of these tokens imply a choice to be made between two
alternatives (26/41, 63.4 %). An even larger majority (35, 87.8 %) occurs in an irrealis
context, which is a well-established precursor of disjunctive constructions. The
disjunctive target construction for the complex construction is restricted to irrealis
contexts. We must stress, however, that there's a significant difference between an
inferred interpretation of 'dispute', 'peace', or any other symmetric relation between
the reference points (as in Examples (3) and (4)) and an inferred 'alternativity'
relation between the reference points. The former relations are conceptual, but the
latter is procedural, so it does not contribute to the propositional content. This
procedural status of 'alternativity' is the hallmark of grammaticized disjunctive
constructions -consider the difference between the explicit alternativity encoded by
otherwise, alternatively and the implicit alternativity associated with the gramma-
ticized or (Ariel and Mauri 2019).

construction. 12 We note that these three are not only rare in the Bible, but they also

The Mishnaic bein constructions manifest several formal differences from their
Biblical counterparts, all pointing to greater complexity. The first difference pertains
to the ratio of simple bein constructions (the modified NP is a single plural NP) and
complex bein constructions (the modified NP/PP comprises two distinct NPs). The
number of simple bein constructions is here reduced by half (40/206, 19.4 %, Cf. 38.1 %
in the Bible), while that of complex constructions increases to a solid majority of
80.6 % (166/206), as compared with 61.8 % for Biblical Hebrew. The second added
complexity pertains to bein complements. As befits a preposition, the Biblical bein
complements virtually all NPs. 17 But Mishnaic Hebrew allows adjectives, adverbs
and even clauses (only in the adverbial indifference-disjunctive construction). 18 This
syntactic expansion in complement types, we suggest, testifies to a reanalysis of the
original preposition bein 'within, between' as a connective akin to the conjunctive
'whether' (but only in the adverbial indifference-disjunctive construction).
At the same time, grammaticization is often accompanied by formal compactiza-
tion, i.e., "less form for more meaning" (Hopper and Traugott 2003 [1993]) (see also
Bardenstein 2016). The price of compactization is reduced semantic transparency, of
course. Overt conjoining is no longer transparently indicated in the majority of Mish-
naic bein cases. First, whereas all the Biblical correlative bein constructions involve an
explicit ve 'and', more than two-thirds of the reference points within the correlative
Mishnaic constructions (74/108, 68.5 %) now show juxtaposed phrases: [bein X bein Y].
Second, as much as a third of the Mishnaic complex constructions (54/166, 32.5 %) show
le 'to' instead of a reduplicated bein: [bein X le-Y], rather than the more complex [bein X
u-vein Y]. Unlike bein 'between', le 'to' does not participate in a syntactically symmetric
construction. The construction then is less transparent, since a conceptually symmetric
relation is expressed by a syntactically nonsymmetric structure.

Biblical Hebrew to 1.9 % in Mishnaic Hebrew (4/206). No doubt this is so because the
constructions are no longer necessarily associated with a syntactically symmetric
structure, so it's virtually always left to inference. Especially interesting in this
connection are two sub-constructions where a specific NP that is syntactically and

3.1 The correlative adverbial indifference-disjunctive bein
constructions: combining conjunctive and disjunctive
aspects
The most frequent function observed in Mishnaic Hebrew (e.g., 1c) (107/206, 51.9 %) is
one we're calling correlative adverbial indifference-disjunctive because it is quite
parallel to the function served by the 'or' construction dubbed Indifference adverbial
or by Ariel (2016), as in (17), where the whether…or adverbial exhaustively lists all
the alternatives under which 'it would still be water' holds true: 19
(17)
PHIL: .. But it would still be water. ((1 LINE OMITTED))
(H)… Whether it's a solid, a liquid, or a gas.
(SBC: 026)
Recall that we did find 3 relatively disjunctive bein examples in Biblical Hebrew,
which we classified as free-alternative bein constructions, namely constructions
that combine conjunctive and disjunctive elements. We claim that these free-
alternative constructions hold the key ingredient for the shift from a predomi-
nantly conjunctive to a predominantly disjunctive construction. But before we
demonstrate how small the step is that separates indifference-disjunctive adver-
bials from free-alternative cases we would like to make a more general point. It is
no accident that some constructions combine the seemingly rather different
conjunctive and disjunctive relations. This is because states of affairs may simul-
taneously manifest both conjunctive ('additive') and disjunctive ('alternativity')
aspects. In such cases, the choice between or and and is dictated by the speaker's
choice of construal.
As argued by Ariel and Mauri (2019), overt conjoining does not preclude an
inferred 'alternativity' (hence, disjunctive) relation between the conjuncts. Consider
Example (18) in which they cite:
(18)
Many treatments, including steroids, gabapentin, acupuncture, heat or ice,
and spinal manipulation, have poor evidence for their use.
(Wikipedia, 29 Jan 2023)
The source cited in (18) lists six examples of treatments for sciatica, all claimed to be
ineffective. However, the speaker did not choose to construe them as a list of six
parallel alternatives. Instead, five types of treatment are profiled as members of an
additive list: steroids, gabapentin, acupuncture, spinal manipulation, and crucially,
some temperature-changing treatment (i.e., heat and ice), the latter two being

The category under discussion in (24) is 'hair-made threads'. Now, as is well-known,
the set of contextually adjusted denotations associated with lexical items is often
narrowed to only a subset of the potential denotations of those expressions (Carston
2002). The adverbial indifference-disjunctive construction in (24) has a metalinguistic
function in effect, in that it guides the addressee on how to interpret 'hair-made

strengthens the propositional content of the utterance (making sure it applies to more

because of its metalinguistic flavor, but we have no evidence for this. 21

descendants (see Bardenstein 2021 and above on the persistence of argumentative
direction across diachronic changes).

reference points are quite common (totaling almost half of the cases), the frequency
of simple bein constructions is drastically reduced. More dramatically, unlike in
Biblical Hebrew, the dominant function served by the complex bein constructions in
Mishnaic Hebrew is the predominantly disjunctive indifference-disjunctive adver-
bial. This construction has a collocative sub-construction [bein kax u-vein kax], which
will play a role in Diaspora and Contemporary Hebrew as well.
4 Diaspora Hebrew: establishing disjunctiveness,
creating generic and subset readings, and
shifting towards 'anyway'
Hebrew was not spoken from approx. the 3rd century up to the 19th century. But we have
written sources for Diaspora Hebrew from 800 to 1800 (the Ma'agarim corpus -see Note 15
again). We extracted 46-48 random examples for every 200-year period, 238 tokens in
total. While there are frequency fluctuations between the 5 periods, these are mostly

irrelevant to the evolutionary path we are tracing for bein. More generally, Diaspora
Hebrew bein mostly shows the same Biblical and Mishnaic functions and constructions.
Surprisingly perhaps, it often seems closer to Biblical Hebrew than to Mishnaic Hebrew.
4.1 Establishing disjunctiveness
Recall that Biblical Hebrew had no adverbial indifference-disjunctive cases, but more
than half of Mishnaic Hebrew bein constructions were of the indifference type. Dias-
pora Hebrew has 80/238, 33.6 %. As for distinguishing disjunctive and non-disjunctive
functions, doubly marked cases are still the majority for disjunctive uses (67/80, 83.4 %),
but adverbial indifference-disjunctive cases are no longer doubly marked as they were
in Mishnaic Hebrew.
Still, Diaspora Hebrew does introduce several disjunctive constructions and
functions, which will also be attested in Revival and Contemporary Hebrew. Like
Mishnaic Hebrew, Diaspora Hebrew too adds complementizer še 'that' when one or
both disjuncts are sentential, but it also introduces the variant im 'if, whether'
complementizer, which is the dominant pattern in Contemporary Hebrew.
(28)
Bein
im magia u-vein
lo
magia
whether if arrives and-whether not arrives
'Whether he arrives or not'
(Sherira ben Hananya Gaon, before 1038)
Next, we have seen that adverbial indifference-disjunctive bein constructions may be
used interchangeably with [X o Y] 'X or Y' constructions in Mishnaic Hebrew. Dias-
pora Hebrew supports our suggestion that the complex bein construction has actu-
ally undergone reanalysis as a disjunctive construction. 8 of the indifference-
disjunctive adverbials (10 %) show o 'or' instead of the duplicate bein, [bein X o Y]
'whether X or Y', as in: 22
(29)

'Whether they are barren or fruit-bearing trees…'
(Abraham ben Mordechai Farissol 1586)

same is true for the [im X im Y] 'if X if Y' construction discussed above, which also has an o
'or' variant in place of the second im 'if': [im X o Y] 'if X or Y'. According to Ariel (2018),

the whole conjunction (see the structure in 5), and is reanalyzed as an 'irrealis' marker, 23

discussed in this article (free-alternative and indifference-disjunctive adverbial). It is
the second occurrence of bein/im, which governs the second option and profiles an
'alternativity' relation between them, that is potentially reanalyzed as an 'or'. Hence only
the second bein (and im 'if') is replaceable by o 'or'. Ironically perhaps, it is this o
substitution that will trigger the fall of the indifference-disjunctive bein construction
later on.
4.1.1 Bein kax 'whether thus' sub-constructions
We already noted that [bein kax u-vein kax] 'whether thus and whether thus' was part
of a specialized sub-construction in Mishnaic Hebrew, used for argumentative
strengthening. A search for the string bein kax in Diaspora Hebrew yielded 5 formal
variants. Interestingly, these variants mirror the very same increasing compactization
of the general complex bein constructions we saw for the three periods above. The only
difference is that the alternatives here are restricted to the deictic kax (or ko) 'thus',
and the 5th variant (e) is a reduced construction containing only one kax 'thus':
(30)
a. bein kax u-vein kax 'whether thus and whether thus'
b. bein kax le-xax 'whether thus to thus'
c. bein kax ve-xax 'whether thus and thus'
d. bein kax o kax 'whether thus or thus'
e. bein kax 'whether thus'
Analyzing or constructions, Ariel and Mauri (2018) found that an extremely frequent
function of these constructions is what they called the higher-level-category use. In such
cases, the distinct alternatives listed by the speaker are taken to point to a single higher-
level category, and it is this abstract entity that is speaker intended. For example, the
whale or the polar bear (SBC: 003) refers to the single, higher-level category of 'endan-
gered animals' (in that context). The denotation of this abstract category, often ad hocly
constructed, is not restricted to the members mentioned explicitly, since the higher-level
category often includes additional members ('grizzly bears', for example).
Now, deictics are often mobilized as indefinite references in dedicated conjunctive
constructions (e.g., this that and the other thing, this or that). If this denotes 'some
indefinite entity' and that denotes 'some other indefinite entity' a higher-level category
reading yields 'an unspecified item of a wide-range, yet context-relevant set', in other
words, 'any (relevant) entity'. Such an evolution makes sense because indifference-

4.2 Simple bein construction evolutions
The main focus of our article is bein evolutions for the complex (double ground)
constructions. We therefore only briefly discuss two new functions that evolved in
Diaspora Hebrew for the simple [bein NPs] construction. Six bein NPs tokens show an
interesting metaphorical extension of the original locative function. For comparison
purposes, we here repeat the classical locative case cited as (1a):
(36)

In such cases, the point of the utterance is to assert that the figure ('it') is physically
located somewhere among the ground entities ('the living creatures'). In the
following example, a disease is asserted to metaphorically exist among the ground
entities:

Note, however, that just like in the English use of among here, the disease doesn't exist
in some metaphorical space between the set of villagers, but rather, within each
villager. In other words, each entity of the ground constitutes an independent ground
within which an instance of the figure (disease) metaphorically exists. We call this the
generic function because the ground must be construed as a relevant general category
with multiple individual members (here, 'villagers'), and the predicate then asserts
that some typical property (here, 'having the terrible disease') is true of the members.
Although syntactically part of the VP, the bein ground in these cases is topical.
Note that while the argumentative point in the generic use concerns the whole
category, realistically, interlocutors do not assume that the property applies to each
member. More likely, the property is true only of a (representative) subset of the
category ('a subset of the villagers'). This reasonable inference must have paved the

outset not distinguishable from the members of the category introduced by the
ground (people of later generations). The ground is here partitioned by bein for a
subset of it to become the figure. The predication then applies to the figure alone. The
following subset example is noteworthy because a descendent of it (exemplification)

the figure is not only introduced as a subset of some whole. It is at the same time also
construed as one among multiple subsets of that whole.
In other words, in the classical locative case, the (specifically locative) predica-
tion is about the figure. In the generic use, the figure, a property, is predicated as
typical of the ground, the category as a whole. In the subset use some property (not
necessarily a typical one) is predicated on a delineated subset of the category, defined
as a figure by the construction.

6.1 From disjunctive to conjunctive bein constructions
A striking fact about Contemporary Hebrew bein is the paucity of disjunctive uses.
free-alternative, which was always extremely rare, is not attested at all, and the
indifference-disjunctive adverbial is now quite rare too (9, 4.8 %), and practically
limited to sentential (rather than phrasal) alternatives. We propose that the decrease
in adverbial indifference-disjunctive use (ever since the 15th century, in fact) is
mostly due to genre change -only Mishnaic Hebrew is rule oriented and needs to
clarify the circumstances under which rules apply. But an additional factor is the
gradual, partial, and later total replacement of the original bein X u-vein Y con-
struction by alternative forms. These were motivated by both compactization and
reanalysis. For example, while 79.2 % of Biblical complex constructions contained a
reduplicate bein token, only 21.3 % currently do. The many cases where the second
connective was replaced by o 'or' testify to a reanalysis of some of the complex bein
constructions as (specialized) disjunctive constructions, and these served as impetus
for a wholesale replacement of the original indifference-disjunctive adverbial. The
same is true for other substitutions of the second bein: ve 'and', le 'to', a hyphen, and a
few other prepositions.
No wonder we can identify a typical discourse profile for the adverbial indif-
ference-disjunctive construction. First, in all cases, at least one of the alternatives is
prefaced by im 'if' in addition to bein 'whether' (9/9). Second, 3/9 involve a specific
collocation, bein im medubar, literally 'whether if spoken', 'whether we're talking
about'. Indeed, an additional search for 100 random bein im strings (98 cases here
included) revealed that medubar is part of the construction in 25 of these, more than a
quarter. Third, as attested for English (Ariel 2016), in as many as 16.3 % the subse-
quent alternative is an elliptical im lo/lav 'if/or not'. Finally, and most crucially, more
than a third (34.7 %) introduce the conventional o 'or' instead of or in addition to the
second bein.
Interestingly, the decrease in disjunctive constructions is accompanied by a rise
in innovative conjunctive uses. Now, we have seen above that certain conjunctive
bein constructions were reinterpreted as disjunctive (see Section 3). However, the
shift between conjunctive and disjunctive constructions is not unidirectional, which
is why a disjunctive construction can also become conjunctive. Of course, such shifts
are restricted to cases where the listed items can simultaneously be construed as
both additive and alternative to each other. Lists are just that. Five examples (2.7 %)
show a list reading: 25

Summing up, Contemporary Hebrew mostly reflects a fall in disjunctive complex
bein constructions in favor of conjunctive functions: list and exemplification. The
simple construction has also come to be used for exemplification, but it can now also
serve to assert category membership for specific (rather than generic) entities. See
Figure 1 for the complete grammaticization clines of Hebrew bein 'between'.
7 Conclusions
Sections 2-6 provided a detailed description of the evolution of Hebrew bein, from its
early Biblical use as a preposition meaning 'within/among', up to current Hebrew, where
it is (among many other things) part of a lexicalized sentence adverbial. The following
schema summarizes the main phases that the bein constructions went through. The first
line for each phase specifies the meaning of bein (in large bold English font), followed by
the complement type it takes. The syntactic/semantic role of the construction is then
listed in parentheses. The subsequent lines exemplify the specific construction, marking
in bold the relevant constructional components in the transcription, followed by a free
gloss. Where more than one constructional variant is attested, two examples are pro-
vided. If originally cited in the article, we refer to the original citation in parentheses:
Generalizing over the changes we have analyzed, we see a gradual rise in more
complex meanings: from location (physical, concrete) to symmetric relation (abstract),
to Alternativity and to exemplification (the latter two being procedural meanings). We
have also documented a rise in complex structures: PP to P (conjoined NPs), to
conjunctive disjunction. For syntactic integration, we have seen shifts for more inte-
gration (VP-governed adjunct, locative adverb to verbal argument), as well as towards
less integration (VP-governed adjunct to ungoverned correlative adverbial and to
discourse marker). We have seen a shift towards opaqueness (due to compactization),
but also towards transparency (when e.g., the second bein was replaced by o 'or' in
disjunctive constructions). We have observed a shift from a mostly conjunctive con-
struction to a mostly disjunctive one (to indifference-disjunctive adverbial), but then,
also back to a more conjunctive one (exemplification).
For the most part, Hebrew tended to add on bein functions and constructions on
top of the old ones, which is in the spirit of Hopper's (1991) Layering proposal. This is
why most of the functions analyzed for all periods preceding Contemporary Hebrew
are still currently attested. Occasionally, however, some functions ('among NP mass ',
free-alternative) or forms (bein she 'whether that') have disappeared. The frequency
of various functions naturally varies between the different periods but is at least
partly due to genre differences. We suspect that the dominance of legal rulings is

responsible for the exceptionally frequent use of indifference-disjunctive adverbials
in Mishnaic Hebrew. 26
The analysis we offered for the diachronic evolution of Hebrew bein considered
each of its many particular constructional functions, thus demonstrating how small
interpretative and formal changes can account for how speakers must have shifted
from one function to another. But we would now like to draw attention to more
abstract and global trends, which apply to multiple functions but are at least partly
orthogonal to these functions. First, as already mentioned, once the adverbial
indifference construction was mobilized for discourse argumentative strengthening
(in Mishnaic Hebrew), first as an anti-narrowing device, all its descendants, non-
disjunctive ones included, carry this discourse function too, in line with Barden-
stein's Persistence Principle (2021).
A second global change responsible for the multiple functions we observed relates
to the entity focused on by bein. In principle, bein constructions may profile (i) pre-
dominantly the interval between the complement reference points (locative, temporal,
range), (ii) predominantly the reference points themselves (indifference-disjunctive
adverbial, subset, exemplification), or (iii) both the reference points and the interval
(relation, separation). Biblical Hebrew is more or less equally divided between interval
(52.2 %) (i) and the double interval + reference points foci (46.6 %) (iii), but hardly has
any reference points foci (1.2 %) (ii). Contemporary Hebrew, on the other hand, has
many less interval foci (22.5 %) (i), many more reference-points focus (19.8 %) (iii), but
mostly demonstrates the double foci (ii). It is important to note these different potential
foci, for they provide the basis for the different functions we analyzed above. Each
function is associated with its focus. We propose that it is the potential for three distinct
foci for the bein complement that made the rich variety of functions possible. The
individual functions can then be distinguished from one another, at least partially, by
reference to the nature of the reference points, the syntactic status of the construction,
the nature of the relevant verb, as well as additional constructional and sub-
constructional features (e.g., double bein versus single bein etc.).
We end with possible implications for future research. Note that most, if not all, of
the radically different functions we identified for Hebrew bein and its descendants are
present in other languages (as witnessed by the free translations of the examples
above). It would be interesting to look for parallel etymological relations and gram-
maticizations in other languages. While we noted some parallel developments for the
simple Hebrew bein NP construction and English among, we suspect that the functions
encoded by the complex bein constructions are typically not expressed by etymologi-
cally related lexemes in other languages. We propose that it's bein's participation in so

many different Goldbergian constructions that accounts for the rather surprising di-
versity of diachronic changes it underwent (see again Figure 1). Indeed, we're not the
first to underscore the crucial role of specific constructions in language change
(Traugott and Trousdale 2013). Next, we only briefly touched on the functional moti-
vations behind (duplicate) correlative constructions, but these intriguing evolutions
deserve much more empirical and theoretical work. Lastly, we offered a potential
connection between conjunctive and disjunctive constructions (beyond the fact that
both are syntactically symmetric). We proposed that conjunctive constructions within
irrealis contexts may be compatible with an inferred 'alternativity' relation between
the conjuncts and thus lead to a disjunctive construction, and at the same time that
disjunctive constructions used for exemplification may lead to reanalysis as conjunctive
constructions. Future research should explore how prevalent such shifts are.
